table_items.text: Type: Clinical Guidelines Register No: 14007 Status: Public

Implementation of Advanced Practitioner Radiographers to perform and report Clinical Barium Swallow Examinations for Clinics including Out Patient, GP's & In-Patient groups to reduce delays in the patients pathway
Learning Disability hospital liaison lead nurse
Policy to be followed by (target staff)

data.text: Document Review History:
Index
Appendices
Purpose

The purpose of this document is to provide clear guidelines for qualified/trainee-advanced practitioner radiographer led upper gastrointestinal (UGI) examinations for patients attending the Radiology Department.
These guidelines apply to qualified/trainee-advanced practitioner radiographers who undertake barium swallow examinations.
It provides non-medical health care practitioners with a framework for safe and effective practice and defines standards expected for their role.
It is to provide patients with an efficient UGI service responding to their needs using the skills of non-medical Practitioners.
The aim is for the majority of clinic/outpatients, GP's and in-patients who are referred for a Barium Swallow examination (BSe) to be undertaken by Advanced Practitioner Radiographers (APRs).
Introduction
Skill mix and APRs is recognised and encouraged (2012, Team working in Clinical Imaging).
Radiographer led examinations are shown to have many benefits:
To reduce waiting times for patients requiring Barium swallow examinations
To free up Radiologist time to undertake other clinical examinations
To standardise patient care
These guidelines are supported by evidence-based guidance and provide a framework for Radiographers undertaking UGI radiological examinations.
Education and Training
All trainee-advanced practitioner radiographers undertaking UGI speciality training will be assigned a Radiologist mentor and supported by the clinical lead and APR of the fluoroscopy department.

3.2. Radiographers that perform clinical BSe will require postgraduate training that involves attendance at a University to undertake the following modules: Principles of Advanced Practice and Advanced Practice for swallowing disorders.

A minimum training period is required for a trainee-advanced practitioner radiographer to attain a clinical logbook of 50 cases under supervision with an APR or Radiologist for the first 20 cases. Followed by a further 10 cases without direct clinical supervision with the resultant images being checked by the APR/Radiologist before the patient leaves the fluoroscopy department. The clinical logbook is then to be signed off by the APR or Radiologist when the case numbers have been met and they are deemed competent to practice.

Radiographers that will be reporting BSe required postgraduate training that involves attendance at a University to undertake the following modules: Core Skills in Radiological Reporting and Advanced Procedures Reporting at a University.
3.5. A minimum training period is required for the trainee-advanced practitioner radiographer to formulate 150 reports that are verified by the UGI Radiologist.

3.6. CPD is a mandatory requirement for Health Care Professions Council (HCPC) registration. APRs should maintain their competence by keeping up to date with current practice by reading new guidelines and peer reviewed articles.
3.7. APRs are required to attend UGI training days and it is encouraged that they attend the UGI MDT meetings as this will increase their knowledge of pathology and the patient pathway.
Scope of Practice
4.1. This policy applies to Clinic/Outpatient, GP and In-patients that are 18 years old and above.
4.2. APRs can only perform a BSe on paediatrics between 12 to 17 years of age where a hernia or reflux is queried on the referral form.
4.2. Cases that must be referred to the Consultant Radiologists are:
Patients that are beyond the APRs knowledge and experience.
Paediatric patients outside the APRs responsibility.
4.3. The practitioner who has performed the examination except should formulate all reports within an appropriate time frame:
Radiologist to report all paediatric examinations.
Examinations that are beyond the APRs knowledge must be assigned to the radiologist for reporting.
Responsibilities
5.1. The Trust will assume vicarious liability for the actions of non-medical practitioners authorised to work in radiology. This is providing the non-medical practitioner has:
Deemed they are competent to undertake the role.
Undertaken training for UGI examinations.
Been authorised to undertake UGI radiology examinations by the Trust.
Followed the guidelines for Advance Practice.
Confirm membership of the Society of Radiographers.
5.2. The radiology manager should:
Ensure the process for UGI radiographer led examinations is written into clinical and operational policies and that they are current.
Ensure records are maintained for staff authorised to practice UGI Radiographer led examinations.
Ensure that all appropriate training is readily available for staff undertaking this role.

5.3. The consultant radiologist will remain the ‘expert' to whom the advanced practitioner refers when they are at the boundaries of their knowledge, skills or scope of practice and is responsible for the final written report.
5.4. The advanced practitioner is responsible for adhering to the protocol guidelines and training requirements.

5.4.1. The HCPC (2012) states that Registered Practitioners have a professional obligation to provide a ‘duty of care' to their patients. Practitioners are responsible for their own practice and must work within their scope of practice and conform to local policies and guidelines.

5.4.2. Practitioners should be responsible in identifying their training needs and must be able to recognise when a situation is outside their realms of competence and request the help of another clinician.

5.4.3. Practitioners should ensure that all documentation is complete, clear and accurate. If non-registered staff/students are under supervision, it is the responsibility of the registered practitioner to ensure the person has the knowledge and necessary skills to undertake the task and ensure all documentation is completed correctly.
5.4.4. The registered practitioner will retain professional accountability for the appropriateness of any delegation of a task.

5.4.5. Registered practitioners will not be accountable for the decisions and actions taken by the delegated person, however, will be responsible for the overall management of the person in their care. The registered practitioner will also be accountable for the decision to delegate.
5.4.6. The APR will be assisted by a qualified and suitably trained radiographer/radiology nurse or assistant practitioner.
5.4.7. A nominated supervising radiologist must be present in the Radiology Department. This can be the duty radiologist.
Procedure for Radiographer Barium Swallow Examination

6.1. The APR is to follow the standard procedure for BSe's, however, this is only a guide (see Appendix I). Additional projections are to be taken when required to attain visualisation of pathology or patient symptoms.
6.2. Modifications of technique for patients with additional physical or learning needs can be made to the standard procedure where necessary.

6.3. Patients in this category may lack the capacity to give consent to the procedure. The referring clinician should complete an MCA2 form when the radiology request is made. The appropriate Hospital Liaison nurse specialist should be contacted when such a patient is booked.
6.4. Copies of the ‘read easy' instructions for Barium swallow are available for patients requiring them from the Hospital Liaison Nurse Specialist, (see Appendix V).
6.5. Patients with additional communication needs can bring a carer or relative into the examination room. The appropriate hospital liaison nurse can also attend by prior arrangement.
6.5.1. Reasonable adjustments for patients with learning disabilities include
Minimal waiting times
Reducing noise levels as low as possible
Consider lighting levels.
6.5.2. Adjustments for patients with physical examinations may include the following:
Carrying out the examination in a seated position.
Tilting the table back  degrees to enable patients with weight bearing issues
Giving patients the option of a straw if they have poor coordination
6.6. Any unexpected complications during the procedure should be discussed immediately with the supervising radiologist for trainees and the duty radiologist for APRs.
6.7. Aspiration is a known complication of the barium swallow examination (see Appendix II). This protocol must be followed when aspiration occurs.
6.8. Referrals will be accepted from both clinics/outpatient and GP's. Experienced APRs or radiologists can vet the referral forms.

6.9. The written report is provided by the APR and finalised by the UGI consultant radiologist. However, as the barium swallow is a dynamic examination, some pathologies and motility disorders are only visualised in real time. The APR should document this on the request form when any of the following occur to assist with formulating the report.
When a hernia is visualised
Any delay in the passage of barium
Tertiary contractions are visualised
Reflux into the oesophagus occurs or an opening of the gastro oesophageal junction that indicates reflux occurs
Any other significant finding
Implementation & Communication
7.1. Following ratification, the policy will be uploaded to the intranet and website and notified to staff.
7.2. The author will email personal copies to all staff with responsibility for implementation.
Breaches of Policy
8.1. The APR will adhere to the Standards of Professional Conduct as detailed by the Health Care Professions Council and Society and College of Radiographers.
8.2. A Risk Event Form may be completed for any APR identified as working outside of their scope of practice or this policy, or in instances of harm or potential harm to patients.
8.3. All breaches will be reviewed by the clinical lead for fluoroscopy to identify any further training required for policy revisions.
Monitoring Compliance and Effectiveness

9.1. To monitor the diagnostic quality of the examinations undertaken by APRs will conduct a 6 monthly audit identifying any cases where the images produced are not diagnostic and the patient has needed to be recalled for further examination. The target for diagnostic quality is 100% with an agreement of 95% when the report is verified.
9.2. All Audits will be presented and discussed at the monthly radiology audit meetings. Targets and improvements will be set and re-audited.
9.3. All breaches identified by audit will be reported as above.
References

Health Care Professions Council. (2012). The Royal College of Radiologists and the Society and College of Radiographers. (Team Working in Clinical Imaging.) [pdf] London: The Royal College of Radiologists and the Society and College of radiographers. Available at http://www.sor.org/printpdf/book/export/HTML/9456 [Accessed 02/01/2014]
Judson, E., & Nightingale, J. (2009). An evaluation of radiographer performed and interpreted barium swallows and meals. Clinical Radiology. 64. 807-814
Nightingale, J. (2008). Developing protocols for advance and consultive practice. Radiography , 14 (1), 55-60.

Royal College of Radiologist. (2016) Standards for the reporting of imaging investigations by non-radiologist medically qualified practitioners. Retrieved from: https://www.rcr.ac.uk/system/files/publication/field_publication_files/bfcr165_non- radiologist_reporting.pdf

Royal College of Radiologists. (2012). The royal college of radiologists and the society and the society and college of radiographers. (Team working in clinical imaging.) [pdf] London: The royal college of radiologists and the society and the society and college of radiographers. Available at http://www.sor.org/sites/default/files/document- versions/BFCR%2812%299 Team.pdf [Accessed
Procedure for Radiographer Led Barium Swallow Examination
Patient Preparation
The patient will be required to change into an x-ray gown and they will be asked to remove necklaces/earings.
Room preparation
The room will be prepared and cleaned before each patient enters. The screening unit will be in the upright position.
Pre examination

Patients' will be brought into the room and introduced to the staff present. Patient ID, consent and previous imaging history will be taken using the referral form. The APR will take a further patient history, answer any questions the patient has and give a full explanation of the procedure to the patient.
Examination
The patient will be safely guided onto the fluoroscopic unit footplate in a standing position.
Standard projections:
Right lateral swallow of the upper oesophagus (to check for any aspiration)
Lateral swallow of the lower oesophagus/ oesophageal gastric junction (GOJ)
AP swallow of the from the buccal cavity tracking the bolus to the stomach
A RAO oblique swallow from the buccal cavity tracking the bolus to the stomach
Prone swallow of the lower oesophagus/GOJ including visualisation of the stomach emptying fluoroscopically
Supine view to include stomach and duodenal loop
Erect stomach view.
The patient is then seated whilst the APR reviews the images to ensure examination is complete.
Post Procedure
The patient is given a wet facial wipe to remove any barium residue from around the mouth.

The patient is instructed how and when to get their results, and warned to drink plenty and expect white faeces as a result of the barium preparation. The patient is then escorted back to the changing cubicle.
The APR will send all the relevant images to PACS and record any comments on the request form for reporting.
The assisting radiographer/assistant practitioner is to post-process the radiographer details and rescan the request form into CRIS.
It is the responsibility of both the APR and the assisting radiographer to ensure the room is cleaned and tidy for the next patient and at the end of the list.
Procedure for Aspiration of Barium
All Barium swallow examinations start in the lateral position. This best demonstrates any aspiration.
If aspiration occurs the lungs should be screened to see quantity and position (left or right bronchus) of any aspirated barium.
The examination should be stopped and the supervising radiologist contacted. If the patient is clinically well:
The radiologist will decide whether the examination continues with water-soluble contrast
Radiologist will decide if patient is fit to leave
If the patient exhibits respiratory distress:
The patient should be administered 2 litres of Oxygen unless they have COPD
The on call respiratory physiotherapist should be bleeped on #6400 313
The patient should be lying on the side opposite to the aspiration
They will be instructed to follow the Active cycle of breathing (see appendix 3)
The patient's SATS will be monitored
The radiologist will contact the medical registrar on call if there is no improvement in the patient's symptoms
On leaving the patient will be instructed to contact their GP if they develop symptoms of a chest infection.
